Abstract

We study KazhdanÂ sets in topological groups which do not necessarily have Property (T). We provide a new criterion for a subset Q of a group G which generates G to be a KazhdanÂ set; it relies on the existence of a positive number Îµ such that every unitary representation of G with a (Q,Îµ)-invariant vector has a finite dimensional subrepresentation. Using this result, we give an equidistribution criterion for a subset of G which generates G to be a KazhdanÂ set. In the case where G=â„¤, this shows that if (nk)kâ‰¥1 is a sequence of integers such that (e2â¢iâ¢Ï€â¢Î¸â¢nk)kâ‰¥1 is uniformly distributed in the unit circle for all real numbers Î¸ except at most countably many, {nk;kâ‰¥1} is a KazhdanÂ set in â„¤ as soon as it generates â„¤. This answers a question of Y.Â Shalom. We also obtain a complete characterization of KazhdanÂ sets in second countable locally compact abelian groups, in the Heisenberg groups, the aâ¢x+b group, and Sâ¢L2â¢(â„). This answers in particular a question from [B.Â Bekka, P.Â de laÂ Harpe, A.Â Valette, Kazhdanâ€™s property (T), Cambridge Univ. Press, 2008]. Lastly, we provide some further applications of KazhdanÂ sets: we generalize a local rigidity result of Rapinchuk, and give a characterization of KazhdanÂ sets in terms of strong ergodicity of groups actions; this last result is related to a characterization of Property (T) due to Connes and Weiss.

Kazhdan sets, topological groups, Property (T), equidistributed sequences in groups, tensor products of unitary representations, weakly mixing representations, compact unitary representations, abstract Wiener theorem, Heisenberg groups, aâ¢x+b group, Howe-Moore property, locally rigid representations, strongly ergodic group actions.

1 Introduction

Property (T) is a rigidity property of topological groups which has been introduced by KazhdanÂ in [35] for locally compact groups, and which has spectacular applications to many fields, such as the study of discrete subgroups of Lie groups, ergodic theory, operators algebras, random walks, explicit constructions of expander graphs and generation of (nearly) uniformly distributed random elements in groups. We refer the reader to the monograph [7] by Bekka, de la Harpe, and Valette for a comprehensive presentation of Kazhdanâ€™s Property (T) and its applications (see also [27]). Among amenable locally compact groups, the only ones which have Property (T) are the compact ones. If K is a local field and nâ‰¥2 is an integer, the groups Sâ¢Lnâ¢(K) have Property (T) if and only if nâ‰¥3. A lattice Î“ in a locally compact group G has Property (T) if and only if G has it, so that for instance the groups Sâ¢Lnâ¢(â„¤) have Property (T) for nâ‰¥3. The group Sâ¢L2â¢(â„¤) does not have Property (T).

Property (T) can be defined as the existence of a KazhdanÂ pair consisting of a compact KazhdanÂ set and its corresponding KazhdanÂ constant (the precise definitions will be given in Section 2 below). Locally compact groups with Property (T) are compactly generated. In particular, discrete groups with Property (T) are finitely generated and it is known (see [7, Prop.Â 1.3.2]) that the KazhdanÂ subsets of a discrete group with Property (T) are exactly the generating subsets of the group. More generally [7, Prop.Â 1.3.2], a generating set of a locally compact group which has Property (T) is a Kazhdan set and, conversely, a Kazhdan set which has non-empty interior is necessarily a generating set. However, the determination of explicit KazhdanÂ pairs in a group with Property (T) is usually a difficult task. This natural problem of identifying KazhdanÂ pairs has been raised by Serre and by de laÂ Harpe and Valette (see [12] and [27, p.Â 133]). Besides these references, we refer the reader to [7, Ch.Â 4], which presents a method of Shalom [51] for obtaining KazhdanÂ pairs for such groups as Sâ¢Lnâ¢(â„¤), nâ‰¥3, [31] which gives the exact asymptotic behaviour, as n goes to infinity, nâ‰¥3, of the Kazhdan constant of the Kazhdan subset of Sâ¢Lnâ¢(â„¤) consisting of the elementary matrices, [56] where KazhdanÂ constants are obtained for certain discrete groups given by presentations, and [5] where it is proved that the unitary group ğ’°â¢(H) of a separable infinite dimensional Hilbert space H, equipped with the strong operator topology, has Property (T), and where explicit finite KazhdanÂ sets in ğ’°â¢(H) are given (in this last example, the group is not locally compact). Notice also that while is not difficult to show that compact groups have Property (T), the computation of Kazhdan constants is nontrivial even for this class of groups; see for instance [44] and the references therein.

Even if a topological group does not have Property (T) it is still interesting to investigate some natural weaker rigidity properties of the group. See for example [40], or [39] which introduces the weaker Property (Ï„). Property (Ï„) is for instance sufficient for applications to expander graphs. It is also an interesting and difficult problem, mentioned in [7, Sec.Â 7.12] to exhibit â€œsmallâ€ KazhdanÂ subsets of groups which do not have Property (T) and, more generally, to determine the class of all KazhdanÂ subsets of such groups.

The main motivations for the present paper are the following two questions of [7, Sec.Â 7.12]. The first one is due to Y.Â Shalom:

Question 1.1

[7, Sec.Â 7.12] â€œThe question of knowing if a subset Q of Z is a KazhdanÂ set is possibly related to the equidistribution of the sequence (e2â¢iâ¢Ï€â¢nâ¢Î¸)nâˆˆQ for Î¸ irrational, in the sense of Weyl.â€

It is not difficult to see that if pâ‰¥2, pâ¢â„¤ is not a KazhdanÂ set in â„¤, while the sequence (e2â¢iâ¢Ï€â¢pâ¢nâ¢Î¸)nâˆˆâ„¤ is uniformly distributed in the circle ğ•‹ for every irrational number Î¸. Also, the set {2k+k;kâ‰¥1} is a KazhdanÂ set in â„¤, while there are irrational numbers Î¸ such that (e2â¢iâ¢Ï€â¢(2k+k)â¢Î¸)kâ‰¥1 is not equidistributed in ğ•‹ (see Example 7.2 and Remark 7.3 below). So Question 1.1 may be rephrased as follows:

Question 1.2

Let Q={nk;kâ‰¥1} be a subset of Z such that the subgroup of Z generated by Q is equal to Z. Suppose that the sequence (e2â¢iâ¢Ï€â¢nkâ¢Î¸)kâ‰¥1 is uniformly distributed in T for every irrational number Î¸. Is Q a KazhdanÂ set in Z?

The second question of [7, Sec.Â 7.12] runs as follows:

Question 1.3

[7, Sec.Â 7.12] â€œMore generally, what are the Kazhdan subsets of Zk, Rk, the Heisenberg group, or other infinite amenable groups?â€

There are several possible ways of defining uniformly distributed sequences in â„¤ and, more generally, in locally compact groups. We refer the reader to the books [37] and [18], and to the papers by Veech [53], [54] and Losert and Rindler [38], [25] for a presentation of various notions of uniform distribution in general locally compact groups. If (gk)kâ‰¥1 is a sequence of elements in a locally compact group G, uniform distribution of (gk)kâ‰¥1 in any of these senses requires a certain form of convergence, as N tends to infinity, of the means

1Nâ¢âˆ‘k=1NÏ€â¢(gk) (1)

to the orthogonal projection PÏ€ on the subspace of invariant vectors for Ï€, for a certain class of unitary representations Ï€ of G. Veech [53], [54] calls (gk)kâ‰¥1 uniformly distributed in G if the convergence of the means (1) holds in the weak operator topology for all unitary representations of G (or, equivalently, for all irreducible unitary representations of G, provided G is supposed to be second countable). Unitary uniform distribution in the sense of Losert and Rindler [38], [25] requires the convergence in the strong operator topology of the means (1) for all irreducible unitary representations of the group, while Hartman uniform distribution only requires convergence in the strong operator topology for all finite dimensional unitary representations. All these notions coincide when G is a Moore group, i.e. when all irreducible unitary representations of the group are finite dimensional. It is essentially obvious that if (gk)kâ‰¥1 is a sequence of elements of a locally compact group G which is uniformly distributed in G in any of these senses, the set {gk;kâ‰¥1} is a KazhdanÂ set in G.

In the case of the group â„¤, the classic Weyl criterion [37] implies that a sequence (nk)kâ‰¥1 of elements of â„¤ is unitarily or Hartman uniformly distributed in â„¤ if and only if the sequence (e2â¢iâ¢Ï€â¢nkâ¢Î¸)kâ‰¥1 is uniformly distributed in ğ•‹ for every Î¸âˆˆâ„âˆ–â„¤, where ğ•‹ denotes as usual the unit circle in â„‚. As observed just above, it is in this case straightforward to show that {nk;kâ‰¥1} is a KazhdanÂ set in â„¤. Now, it is in many settings much more convenient and natural to consider the weaker equidistribution condition that (e2â¢iâ¢Ï€â¢Î¸â¢nk)kâ‰¥1 is uniformly distributed in ğ•‹ for every Î¸âˆˆâ„âˆ–â„š: this is the condition which appears in Shalomâ€™s Question 1.1. It is of course a weaker requirement on (nk)kâ‰¥1 than that of being Hartman uniformly distributed, and the sequence (nk)kâ‰¥1 given by nk=k2 verifies the equidistribution condition of QuestionÂ 1.1 although it is not Hartman uniformly distributed in â„¤.

We will consider in this paper a natural extension to general locally compact groups G of the equidistribution condition of Question 1.1: if (gk)kâ‰¥1 is a sequence of elements of G, we require the means (1) to converge for all finite dimensional unitary representations of G except at most countably many. In the case of the group â„¤, sequences (nk)kâ‰¥1 of integers such that (e2â¢iâ¢Ï€â¢Î¸â¢nk)kâ‰¥1 is uniformly distributed in ğ•‹ for all Î¸âˆˆâ„ except countably many are said to be of first kind (see for instance [29]). The generalization of Question 1.2 to this setting runs as follows:

Question 1.4

Let (gk)kâ‰¥1 be a sequence of elements of a locally compact group G which satisfies the following equidistribution property:

for all finite dimensional irreducible unitary representations Ï€ of G on a Hilbert space H, except at most countably many, \xymatrixâ¢@â¢C=50â¢pâ¢tâ¢1Nâ¢âˆ‘k=1NâŸ¨Ï€â¢(gk)â¢x,yâŸ©â¢\arâ¢[r]-â¢\xymatrixâ¢@C=13ptN\ar[r]&+â¢âˆâ¢&â¢0â€ƒfor everyâ¢x,yâˆˆH. (2)

When is it true that Q={gk;kâ‰¥1} is a KazhdanÂ set in G?

We provide in this work an answer to Question 1.4 when G is a second countable Moore group, and thus fully answer Shalomâ€™s Question 1.1 as well. We also answer Question 1.3 by giving a complete description of Kazhdan sets in many classic groups which do not have Property (T), including the groups â„¤k and â„k, kâ‰¥1, and the Heisenberg groups of all dimensions. Let us now describe our main results in more detail.

2 Main results

We first briefly set down some notation and recall some important definitions.

2.1 Definitions and notation

The Hilbert spaces will always be supposed in this paper to be complex, and endowed with an inner product âŸ¨â‹…,â‹…âŸ© which is linear in the first variable and antilinear in the second variable. A unitary representation of G on H is a group morphism from G into the group ğ’°â¢(H) of all unitary operators on H which is strongly continuous, i.â€‰e.Â such that the map \xymatrixâ¢gâ¢\arâ¢@â¢|->â¢[r]â¢&â¢Ï€â¢(g)â¢x is continuous from G into H for all vectors xâˆˆH. As all the representations we consider in this paper are unitary, we will often drop the word â€œunitaryâ€ and speak simply of representations of a group G on a Hilbert space H.

Definition 2.1

Let Q be a subset of a topological group G, Îµ a positive real number, and Ï€ a unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H. A vector xâˆˆH is said to be (Q,Îµ)-invariant for Ï€ if

supgâˆˆQâ¡||Ï€â¢(g)â¢x-x||<Îµâ¢||x||.

A (Q,Îµ)-invariant vector for Ï€ is in particular non-zero. A G-invariant vector for Ï€ is a vector xâˆˆH such that Ï€â¢(g)â¢x=x for all gâˆˆG.

The notions of KazhdanÂ sets and KazhdanÂ pairs will be fundamental in our work.

Definition 2.2

A subset Q of a topological group G is a KazhdanÂ set in G if there exists Îµ>0 such that the following property holds true: any unitary representation Ï€ of G on a complex Hilbert space H with a (Q,Îµ)-invariant vector has a non-zero G-invariant vector. In this case, the pair (Q,Îµ) is KazhdanÂ pair, and Îµ is a KazhdanÂ constant for Q. A group G has Property (T), or is a KazhdanÂ group, if it admits a compact KazhdanÂ set.

Lastly, we introduce a generating property of a subset of a group, which is weaker that the notion of generating set as used for instance in [7].

Definition 2.3

If Q is any subset of a group G, we denote by âŸ¨QâŸ© the smallest subgroup of G containing Q, i.â€‰e.Â the set of all elements of the form g1Â±1â¢â€¦â¢gnÂ±1, where nâ‰¥1 and g1,â€¦,gn belong to Q. We say that Q generates G if âŸ¨QâŸ©=G. It is equivalent to requiring that Q~=QâˆªQ-1 be a generating set in the sense of [7, Sec.Â 7.1].

2.2 Equidistributed sets in Moore groups

Our first main result provides a complete answer to Question 1.4 when the group G is a second countable Moore group, i.â€‰e.Â when all irreducible representations of G are finite dimensional. Locally compact Moore groups are completely described in [43]: a Lie group is a Moore group if and only if it has a closed subgroup H such that H modulo its center is compact, and a locally compact group is a Moore group if and only if it is a projective limit of Lie groups which are Moore groups. See also the survey [46] for more information concerning the links between various properties of topological groups, among them the property of being a Moore group. Of course all locally compact abelian groups are Moore groups.

Theorem 2.4

Let G be a second countable locally compact Moore group. Let Q be a subset of G of the form Q={gk;kâ‰¥1} where (gk)kâ‰¥1 is a sequence of elements of G. Suppose that Q generates G, and that (gk)kâ‰¥1 satisfies the following assumption:

for all (finite dimensional) irreducible unitary representations Ï€ of G on a Hilbert space H, except at most countably many, \xymatrixâ¢@â¢C=50â¢pâ¢tâ¢1Nâ¢âˆ‘k=1NâŸ¨Ï€â¢(gk)â¢x,yâŸ©â¢\arâ¢[r]-â¢\xymatrixâ¢@C=13ptN\ar[r]&+â¢âˆâ¢&â¢0â€ƒfor everyâ¢x,yâˆˆH. (3)

Then Q is a KazhdanÂ set in G.

As explained in the introduction, property (3) above is an equidistribution property of the sequence (gk)kâ‰¥1. It takes a more familiar form when the group G is supposed to be abelian: it is equivalent to requiring that condition (4) below holds true for all characters Ï‡ of the group except possibly countably many.

Theorem 2.5

Let G be a locally compact abelian group, and let (gk)kâ‰¥1 be a sequence of elements of G. Suppose that Q={gk;kâ‰¥1} generates G, and that

\xymatrixâ¢@â¢C=50â¢pâ¢tâ¢1Nâ¢âˆ‘k=1NÏ‡â¢(gk)â¢\arâ¢[r]-â¢\xymatrixâ¢@C=13ptğ‘\ar[r]&+â¢âˆâ¢&â¢0 (4)

Theorem 2.5 can thus be seen as a particular case of Theorem 2.4, except for the fact that there is no need to suppose that the group is second countable when it is known to be abelian. Specializing Theorem 2.5 to the case where G=â„¤, we obtain the following complete answer to Question 1.2 above:

Let (nk)kâ‰¥1 be a sequence of elements of Z, and set Q={nk;kâ‰¥1}. Suppose that the sequence (e2â¢iâ¢Ï€â¢nkâ¢Î¸)kâ‰¥1 is equidistributed in the unit circle T for all real numbers Î¸ except at most countably many. The following assertions are equivalent:

  2. (b)

2.3 Kazhdan sets and finite dimensional subrepresentations

The proof of Theorem 2.5 relies on Theorem 2.7 below, which gives a new condition for a â€œsmall perturbationâ€ of a subset Q of a group G to be a KazhdanÂ set in G. Theorem 2.7 constitutes the core of the paper, and has, besides the proofs of Theorems 2.4, 2.5, and 2.6, several interesting applications which we will present in Sections 7 and 8.

Theorem 2.7

Let G be a topological group, and let (Wn)nâ‰¥1 be an increasing sequence of subsets of G such that W1 is a neighborhood of the unit element e of G and â‹ƒ\gnW=nG. Let Q be a subset of G satisfying the following assumption:

there exists a positive constant Îµ such that every unitary representation Ï€ of G on a Hilbert space H admitting a ( Q , Îµ ) -invariant vector has a finite dimensional subrepresentation. (*)

Then there exists an integer nâ‰¥1 such that Qn=WnâˆªQ is a KazhdanÂ set in G.

If the group G is locally compact, the same statement holds true for any increasing sequence (Wn)nâ‰¥1 of subsets of G such that â‹ƒ\gnW=nG (we no longer need to request that W1 be a neighborhood of e).

If the group G is locally compact and Ïƒ-compact, we can choose for (Wn)nâ‰¥1 an increasing sequence of compact sets whose union is equal to G. If Q is a subset of G satisfying (* â€£ 2.7), there exists then by Theorem 2.7 a compact subset L of G such that LâˆªQ is a KazhdanÂ set in G. We thus retrieve a characterization of Property (T) for Ïƒ-compact locally compact groups due to Bekka and Valette [6], see also [7, Th.Â 2.12.9]. The original proof of this result relies on the Delorme-Guichardet theorem that such a group has Property (T) if and only if it has property (FH), that is every affine isometric action of G on a real Hilbert space has a fixed point. See Section 6 for more details.

Theorem 2.7 admits a simpler formulation if we build the sequence (Wn)nâ‰¥1 starting from a set which generates the group in the sense of Definition 2.3:

Corollary 2.8

Let G be a topological group. Let Q0 be a subset of G which generates G and has non-empty interior, and Q a subset of G. If Q satisfies assumption (* â€£ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7, Q0âˆªQ is a KazhdanÂ set in G.

If G is a locally compact group, it suffices to assume that Q0 generates G in order to obtain the same conclusion.

One of the main consequences of Corollary 2.8 is Theorem 2.9 below, which shows in particular that property (* â€£ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7 characterizes KazhdanÂ sets among sets which generate the group (and have non-empty interior â€“ this assumption has to be added if the group is not supposed to be locally compact).

Theorem 2.9

Let G be a topological group and let Q be a subset of G which generates G and has non-empty interior. Then the following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (a)

    Q is a KazhdanÂ set in G;

  2. (b)

    there exists a constant Î´âˆˆ(0,1) such that every unitary representation Ï€ of G on a Hilbert space H admitting a vector xâˆˆH such that infgâˆˆQâ¡|âŸ¨Ï€â¢(g)â¢x,xâŸ©|>Î´â¢âˆ¥xâˆ¥2 has a finite dimensional subrepresentation;

  3. (c)

    there exists a positive constant Îµ such that every unitary representation Ï€ of G on a Hilbert space H admitting a (Q,Îµ)-invariant vector has a finite dimensional subrepresentation.

If the group G is locally compact and Q generates G, assertions (a), (b) and (c) above are equivalent.

Condition (b) in Theorem 2.9 is easily seen to be equivalent to condition (c), which is nothing else than assumption (* â€£ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7. Its interest will become clearer in Section 7 below, where it will be used to obtain a characterization of Kazhdan sets in second countable locally compact abelian groups.

The assumption that Q generates G cannot be dispensed with in Theorem 2.9: Q=2â¢â„¤ is a subset of â„¤ which satisfies property (c), but Q is clearly not a KazhdanÂ set in â„¤, while {1}âˆªQ is one. Indeed, if G is a discrete group, a KazhdanÂ subset Q of G must necessarily generate G (see [7, Prop.Â 1.3.2]). Hence Theorem 2.9 can be reformulated in the case of discrete groups so as to give a complete characterization of KazhdanÂ sets in G in terms of assumption (* â€£ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7:

Theorem 2.10

Let G be a discrete group, and let Q be a subset of G. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (a)

    Q is a KazhdanÂ set in G;

  2. (b)

    Q generates G, and there exists a constant Î´âˆˆ(0,1) such that every unitary representation Ï€ of G on a Hilbert space H for which there exists a vector xâˆˆH such that infgâˆˆQâ¡|âŸ¨Ï€â¢(g)â¢x,xâŸ©|>Î´â¢âˆ¥xâˆ¥2 has a finite dimensional subrepresentation;

  3. (c)

    Q generates G, and there exists a positive constant Îµ such that every unitary representation Ï€ of G on a Hilbert space H admitting a (Q,Îµ)-invariant vector has a finite dimensional subrepresentation.

2.4 Examples and applications

We characterize KazhdanÂ sets in various groups in which irreducible unitary representations are completely described. Using the new criterion provided by Theorem 2.9, we first provide such a characterization of KazhdanÂ sets in second countable locally compact abelian groups (Theorem 7.4). In the case of the group â„¤, the characterization we obtain (Theorem 7.6) involves a classic class of sets in hamonic analysis, called Kaufman sets. We also present some examples of KazhdanÂ sets in this setting. We then describe KazhdanÂ sets in the Heisenberg groups Hn, nâ‰¥1 (Theorem 7.12) and in the aâ¢x+b group (Theorem 7.15). We finally study KazhdanÂ sets in groups with the Howe-Moore property, and obtain a complete characterization of KazhdanÂ sets in groups with the Howe-Moore property but without Property (T) (Theorem 7.17), which yields a description of KazhdanÂ sets in Sâ¢L2â¢(â„). See Section 7 for detailed statements of these results, which provide an answer to Question 1.3.

We also obtain two further applications of KazhdanÂ sets. The first one (Theorem 8.1) is a generalization of a result of Rapinchuk [49] concerning the local rigidity of finite dimensional unitary representations in discrete groups with Property (T). The second application (Theorem 8.3) consists in a version for KazhdanÂ sets of a characterization of Property (T) due to Connes and Weiss [16]. Namely, we prove that if Q is a subset of a topological group G which generates G, it is a KazhdanÂ set in G if and only if every weakly mixing action of G on a probability space is Q-strongly ergodic (see Section 8.2 for definitions). These applications highlight one more time the importance of determining KazhdanÂ sets in general groups.

2.5 Organization of the paper

The first half of the paper is devoted to the proof of Theorem 2.9. Section 3 is mostly expository, and presents some essential results and tools concerning ergodic theory for unitary representations of arbitrary topological groups. Section 4 is devoted to the proof of an abstract version of the Wiener Theorem (Theorem 4.7): if Ï€ is any unitary representation of a topological group G on a Hilbert space H, Theorem 4.7 provides an explicit expression for the quantities mGâ¢(|âŸ¨Ï€â¢(âˆ™)â¢x,yâŸ©|2), x,yâˆˆH, where mG is the unique invariant mean on WAP(G). This theorem is crucial for the proof of Theorem 2.7, which proceeds by contradiction: we use Theorem 4.7 to show that certain infinite tensor products of finite dimensional representations are weakly mixing. The proof of Theorem 2.7 is given in Section 5. The equidistribution criteria for KazhdanÂ sets (Theorems 2.4, 2.5 and 2.6) are proved in Section 6, as well as Corollary 2.8, Theorem 2.9 and Corollary 2.10. Section 7 is devoted to examples; the characterizations of KazhdanÂ sets in second countable locally compact abelian groups, and in â„¤ in particular, in the Heisenberg groups, the aâ¢x+b group, and groups with the Howe-Moore property are proved in Theorems 7.4, 7.6, 7.12, 7.15 and 7.17 respectively. The extensions of the Rapinchuk rigidity result [49] and of the Connes-Weiss characterization of Property (T) [16] are proved in Section 8. The paper also contains an appendix which reviews some constructions of infinite tensor products of Hilbert spaces and of unitary representations, which are used in the proof of Theorem 2.7.

3 Ergodic theory and mixing properties for unitary representations of topological groups

The proof of our main theorem will require a rather precise knowledge of the structure of unitary representations of a topological group G. We first recall in this section some definitions and results that we will need. They can be found for instance in the forthcoming book [36], the notes [47], and the paper [9] by Bergelson and Rosenblatt.

Let Ï€ be a unitary representation of G on a complex Hilbert space H. In the case where G=â„¤, the well-known (weak) ergodic theorem of von Neumann states that if U is a unitary operator on H,

\xymatrixâ¢1Nâ¢âˆ‘n=1NâŸ¨Unâ¢x,yâŸ©â¢\arâ¢[r]â¢&â¢âŸ¨Pâ¢x,yâŸ©

as N tends to infinity for every vectors x,yâˆˆH, where P denotes the orthogonal projection in H onto the subspace kerâ¡(U-I) of fixed points of U. This result admits an extension to amenable groups (see [17] or [19]) and, by using the existence of an invariant mean on weakly almost periodic functions on G, to all topological groups. Recall that the class WAP(G) of weakly almost periodic functions on G is defined as follows: if â„“âˆâ¢(G) denotes the space of bounded functions on G, fâˆˆâ„“âˆâ¢(G) belongs to WAP(G) if the weak closure in â„“âˆâ¢(G) of the set {f(s-1âˆ™);sâˆˆG} is weakly compact. For each sâˆˆG, f(s-1âˆ™) denotes the function \xymatrixâ¢tâ¢\arâ¢@â¢|->â¢[r]â¢&â¢fâ¢(s-1â¢t) on G. By comparison, recall that fâˆˆâ„“âˆâ¢(G) is an almost periodic function on G, written fâˆˆAP(G), if the norm closure in â„“âˆâ¢(G) of {f(s-1âˆ™);sâˆˆG} is compact. If Ï€ is a unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H, the functions

Proposition 3.1

  1. (1)

    Ï€ is weakly mixing;

    Ï€ admits no finite dimensional subrepresentation;

  3. (3)

    Ï€âŠ—Ï€Â¯ has no non-zero G-invariant vector.

A companion to the property of weak mixing for unitary representation is that of compactness: given a unitary representation Ï€ of G on H a vector xâˆˆH is compact for Ï€ if the norm closure of the set {Ï€â¢(g)â¢x;gâˆˆG} is compact in H. The representation Ï€ itself is said to be compact if every vector of H is compact for Ï€. Compact representations decompose as direct sums of irreducible finite dimensional representations. A representation Ï€ is weakly mixing if and only if the only compact vector for Ï€ is the zero vector. The general structural result for unitary representations is given by Proposition 3.2. It extends a well-known result of Jacobs, de Leeuw and Glicksberg (see for instance [22] for an account of this result) which associates to any contraction T on a Hilbert space H a decomposition of H into two T- and T*-invariant subspaces of T. This two spaces correspond respectively to the weakly mixing and compact parts in the statement below.

Proposition 3.2

A unitary representation Ï€ of G on a Hilbert space H decomposes as a direct sum of a weakly mixing representation and a compact representation:

H=Hwâ¢âŠ•âŸ‚Hc,

where Hw and Hc are both G-invariant closed subspaces of H, Ï€w=Ï€|Hw is weakly mixing and Ï€c=Ï€|Hc is compact. Hence Ï€ decomposes as a direct sum of a weakly mixing representation and finite dimensional irreducible subrepresentations.

See [47, Ch.Â 1], [7, AppendixÂ M], [9] or [19] (in the amenable case) for detailed proofs of these results.

5 Proof of Theorem 2.7

5.1 Notation

5.3 KazhdanÂ property for ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations

In order to complete the proof of Theorem 2.7, we need to consider separately two cases, depending on whether or not infinitely many of the non-KazhdanÂ sets Qn satisfy a weak form of the KazhdanÂ property, which we call the KazhdanÂ property for ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations. Let us first introduce the following definition.

Definition 5.2

Let C be a class of representations of G on a Hilbert space. We say that a subset Q of G is a KazhdanÂ set for the class ğ’ if there exists a positive constant Îµâ€² such that the following holds true: if Ï€ is a representation of G belonging to C which admits a (Q,Îµâ€²)-invariant vector, then Ï€ has a non-zero G-invariant vector.

Kazhdanâ€™s Property (T) for particular classes of representations is a much studied topic. For instance Property (Ï„) for discrete groups (see, among other references [32] or [41]) is Property (T) for the class of representations which factor through a finite index subgroup.

We will consider here the class ğ’0 consisting of all ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations of G. These are the representations of G of the form

6.2 Property (T) in Ïƒ-compact locally compact groups

As a consequence of Theorem 2.7, we retrieve a characterization of Property (T) due to Bekka and Valette [6], [7, Th.Â 2.12.9], valid for Ïƒ-compact locally compact groups. Recall that a unitary representation Ï€ of G on a Hilbert space H has almost-invariant vectors if it has (Q,Îµ)-invariant vectors for every compact subset Q of H and every Îµ>0. Then Property (T) can be characterized by the fact that every unitary representation of G with almost-invariant vectors has a non-zero G-invariant vector [7, Prop.Â 1.2.1]. A result due to Bekka and Valette [6] (see also [7, Th. 2.12.9]) states the following:

Theorem 6.1 ([6])

Let G be a Ïƒ-compact locally compact group. Then G has Property (T) if and only if every unitary representation of G with almost-invariant vectors has a non-trivial finite dimensional subrepresentation.

The proof of [6] relies on the equivalence between Property (T) and Property (FH) for such groups [7, Th.Â 2.12.4]: every affine isometric action of G on a real Hilbert space has a fixed point. As a direct consequence of Theorem 2.7, we will derive a new proof of Theorem 6.1 which does not involve property (FH).

If Q is a subset of a topological group G, and if Ï€ is a unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H, we say that Ï€ has Q-almost-invariant vectors if it has (Q,Îµ)-invariant vectors for every Îµ>0. The same argument as in [7, Prop.Â 1.2.1] shows that Q is a KazhdanÂ set in G if and only if every representation of G with Q-almost-invariant vectors has a non-zero G-invariant vector. As a direct corollary of Theorem 2.9, we obtain the following characterization of KazhdanÂ sets which generate the group:

Corollary 6.2

Let Q be a subset of a locally compact group G which generates G. Then Q is a KazhdanÂ set in G if and only if every representation Ï€ of G with Q-almost-invariant vectors has a non-trivial finite dimensional subrepresentation.

{proof}

[Proof of Corollary 6.2] The only thing to prove is that if every representation Ï€ of G with Q-almost-invariant vectors has a non-trivial finite dimensional representation, Q is a KazhdanÂ set. For this it suffices to show the existence of an Îµ>0 such that assumption (* â€£ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7 holds true. The argument is again exactly the same as the one given in [7, Prop.Â 1.2.1]: suppose that there is no such Îµ, and let, for every Îµ>0, Ï€Îµ be a representation of G with a (Q,Îµ)-invariant vector but no finite dimensional subrepresentation. Then Ï€=âŠ•Îµ>0Ï€Îµ has Q-almost-invariant vectors but no finite dimensional subrepresentation (this follows immediately from [7, Prop.Â A.1.8]), contradicting our initial assumption.

{proof}

[Proof of Theorem 6.1] It is clear that Property (T) implies that every representation of G with almost-invariant vectors has a non-trivial finite dimensional subrepresentation. Conversely, suppose that every representation of G with almost-invariant vectors has a non-trivial finite dimensional subrepresentation. Using the same argument as in the proof of Corollary 6.2, we see that there exists a compact subset Q of G such that assumption (* â€£ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7 holds true. Choosing for (Wn)nâ‰¥1 an increasing sequence of compact subsets of G such that â‹ƒ\gnW=nG, Theorem 2.7 implies that there exists an nâ‰¥1 such that WnâˆªQ is a KazhdanÂ set in G. Since WnâˆªQ is compact, G has Property (T).

7 Examples and applications

We present in this section some more examples of KazhdanÂ sets in different kinds of groups, some statements being obtained as consequences of Theorems 2.7, 2.9 or 2.10. We do not try to be exhaustive, and our aim here is rather to highlight some interesting phenomena which appear when looking for KazhdanÂ sets, as well as the connections of these phenomena with some remarkable properties of the group. We begin with the simplest case, that of locally compact abelian (LCA) groups.

7.1 KazhdanÂ sets in locally compact abelian groups

Let G be a second countable LCA group, the dual group of which we denote by Î“. If Ïƒ is a finite Borel measure on Î“, recall that its Fourier-Stieljes transform is defined by

Ïƒ^â¢(g)=âˆ«Î“Î³â¢(g)â¢ğ‘‘Ïƒâ¢(Î³)â€ƒfor everyâ¢gâˆˆG.

The spectral theorem for unitary representations of G acting on a (separable) Hilbert space easily yields the following characterization of KazhdanÂ subsets of G in terms of Fourier coefficients of probability measures on Î“.

Proposition 7.1

Let Q be a subset of a second countable LCA group G. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (1)

    Q is a KazhdanÂ set in G;

  2. (2)

    there exists Îµ>0 such that any probability measure Ïƒ on Î“ with supgâˆˆQâ¡|Ïƒ^â¢(g)-1|<Îµ satisfies Ïƒâ¢({1})>0, where 1 denotes the trivial character on G.

Proposition 7.1 is extremely useful to obtain various examples of KazhdanÂ and non-KazhdanÂ sets in classic LCA groups such as â„¤d or â„d. We give here two such examples.

Example 7.2

The set Q={2k+k;kâ‰¥0} is a KazhdanÂ set in Z, while the set Qâ€²={2k;kâ‰¥0} is not a KazhdanÂ set in Z.

{proof}

The sequence (nk)kâ‰¥0 defined by nk=2k+k for every kâ‰¥0 satisfies the relation 2â¢nk=nk+1+k-1 for every kâ‰¥0. If Ïƒ is a probability measure on ğ•‹ such that supkâ‰¥0â¡|Ïƒ^â¢(nk)-1|<1/3, it follows from the fact that

|Ïƒ^â¢(k-1)-1|â‰¤2â¢|Ïƒ^â¢(nk)-1|+|Ïƒ^â¢(nk+1)-1|â€ƒfor allâ¢kâ‰¥1

that supkâ‰¥0â¡|Ïƒ^â¢(k)-1|<1. Hence Ïƒâ¢({1})>0, and Q={nk;kâ‰¥0} is a KazhdanÂ set in â„¤. The fact that Qâ€² is not a KazhdanÂ set in â„¤ relies on the observation that 2k divides 2k+1 for every kâ‰¥0. Using the same construction as the one of [21, Prop.Â 3.9], one can construct for every Îµ>0 a continuous probability measure Ïƒ on ğ•‹, given as an infinite convolution of two-points Dirac measures, such that

supkâ‰¥0â¡|Ïƒ^â¢(2k)-1|<Îµ,

and this proves that Qâ€² is not a KazhdanÂ set in â„¤.

Remark 7.3

The set {2k+k;kâ‰¥0} being lacunary, it follows from a result proved independently by Pollington [48] and De Mathan [42] that there exists a subset A of [0,1] of Hausdorff measure 1 such that for every Î¸ in A, the set of all fractional parts of (2k+k)â¢Î¸, kâ‰¥0, is not dense in [0,1]. One of these numbers Î¸ is irrational, and ((2k+k)â¢Î¸)kâ‰¥0 is of course not uniformly distributed modulo 1.

As a consequence of Theorem 2.9 and of the spectral theorem for unitary representations of the group, we obtain the following characterization of KazhdanÂ sets which generate the group in any second countable LCA group.

Theorem 7.4

Let G be a second countable LCA group, and let Q a subset of G which generates G. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (1)

    Q is a KazhdanÂ set in G;

  2. (2)

    there exists Î´âˆˆ(0,1) such that any probability measure Ïƒ on Î“ with infgâˆˆQâ¡|Ïƒ^â¢(g)|>Î´ has a discrete part;

  3. (3)

    there exists Îµ>0 such that any probability measure Ïƒ on Î“ with supgâˆˆQâ¡|Ïƒ^â¢(g)-1|<Îµ has a discrete part.

It is worth stating explicitly the corresponding characterization of non-KazhdanÂ subsets of G: Q is not a KazhdanÂ subset of G if and only if there exists for every Î´âˆˆ(0,1) a continuous probability measure Ïƒ on Î“ such that infgâˆˆQâ¡|Ïƒ^â¢(g)|>Î´, or, equivalently, if and only if there exists for every Îµ>0 a continuous probability measure Ïƒ on Î“ such that supgâˆˆQâ¡|Ïƒ^â¢(g)-1|<Îµ. If the group G is discrete, Theorem 2.10 combined with the spectral theorem for unitary representations again implies that a subset Q of G is a KazhdanÂ set in G if and only if Q generates G and either assertion (2) or (3) of Theorem 7.4 holds true.

Theorem 7.4 becomes particularly meaningful in the case of the group â„¤, as it yields a characterization of KazhdanÂ subsets of â„¤ involving some classic sets in harmonic analysis, introduced by Kaufman in [33]. They are called w-sets by Kaufman [34], and Kaufman sets (Ka sets) by other authors, such as Hartman [28], [29].

Definition 7.5

Let Q be a subset of Z, and let Î´âˆˆ(0,1).

âˆ™ We say that Q belongs to the class Ka if there exists a finite complex-valued continuous Borel measure Î¼ on T such that infnâˆˆQâ¡|Î¼^â¢(n)|>0, and to the class Î´-Ka if there exists a finite complex-valued continuous Borel measure Î¼ on T with Î¼â¢(T)=1 such that infnâˆˆQâ¡|Î¼^â¢(n)|>Î´.

âˆ™ We say that Q belongs to the class Ka+ if there exists a continuous probability measure Ïƒ on T such that infnâˆˆQâ¡|Ïƒ^â¢(n)|>0, and to the class Î´-Ka+ if there exists a continuous probability measure Ïƒ on T such that infnâˆˆQâ¡|Ïƒ^â¢(n)|>Î´.

Our final characterization of KazhdanÂ subsets of â„¤ is given by Theorem 7.6 below:

Theorem 7.6

Let Q a subset of Z. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (1)

    Q is a KazhdanÂ set in â„¤;

  2. (2)

    Q generates â„¤, and there exists a Î´âˆˆ(0,1) such that Q does not belong to Î´-Ka+.

In particular, if Q generates Z, Q is not a KazhdanÂ subset of Z if and only if Q belongs to Î´-Ka+ for every Î´âˆˆ(0,1).

It is interesting to remark [29] that a set Q belongs to Ka if and only if it belongs to Î´-Ka for every Î´âˆˆ(0,1). There is no similar statement for the class Ka+: any sufficiently lacunary subset of â„¤, such as Q={3k+k;kâ‰¥1}, is easily seen to belong to Ka+; but the same reasoning as in Example 7.2 above shows that this set Q is a KazhdanÂ subset of â„¤. Thus there exists by Theorem 7.6 a Î´âˆˆ(0,1) such that Q does not belong to Î´-Ka+.

Facts 7.11 and 7.14 have played a crucial role in the proofs of Theorems 7.12 and 7.15 respectively, as they allowed us to discard all irreducible representations except the one-dimensional inequalities of the form (16). There are locally compact groups in which all non-trivial irreducible representations have the vanishing property of the matrix coefficients stated in Facts 7.11 or 7.14: these groups are said to have the Howe-Moore property. The study of KazhdanÂ sets becomes easier in such groups, and it is even possible to characterize KazhdanÂ sets in groups which do not have Property (T), but have the Howe-Moore property, such as Sâ¢L2â¢(â„). This is the object of the next section.

7.4 KazhdanÂ sets in groups with the Howe-Moore property

The Howe-Moore property was introduced by Howe and Moore in [30]: a locally compact group G has the Howe-Moore property if whenever Ï€ is a unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H, the following alternative holds true:

  1. â€“

    either Ï€ has a non-zero G-invariant vector;

  2. â€“

    or whenever x and y are two vectors of H, the matrix coefficient âŸ¨Ï€â¢(g)â¢x,yâŸ© vanishes at infinity in the sense that for any Î´>0, the set {gâˆˆG;|âŸ¨Ï€â¢(g)â¢x,yâŸ©|â‰¥Î´} is compact in G.

It was proved in [30] and [55] that connected, non-compact, simple real Lie groups with finite center have the Howe-Moore property. We refer the reader to the references [8], [15], and [14] for more on this topic. If the group G is locally compact and second countable, it follows from the decomposition of unitary representations as direct integrals of irreducible representations that G has the Howe-Moore property if and only if all matrix coefficients of non-trivial irreducible representations vanish at infinity.

The following proposition states that all subsets with non-compact closure are KazhdanÂ sets in groups with the Howe-Moore property. This testifies of the rigidity of the structure of such groups, and stands in sharp contrast with all the examples we have presented until now.

Proposition 7.16

Let G be a locally compact group with the Howe-Moore property, and let Q be a subset of G. If the closure QÂ¯ of Q in G is non-compact, Q is a KazhdanÂ set in G.

{proof}

Let Îµâˆˆ(0,2), and let Ï€ be a representation of G on a Hilbert space H which admits a (Q,Îµ)-invariant vector xâˆˆH, which we suppose to be of norm 1. Then

supgâˆˆQâ¡(1-â„œâ¡eâ¢âŸ¨Ï€â¢(g)â¢x,xâŸ©)<Îµ2,so thatâ¢|âŸ¨Ï€â¢(g)â¢x,xâŸ©|>1-Îµ2â€ƒfor everyâ¢gâˆˆQ.

Suppose that Ï€ has no non-zero G-invariant vector. Since G has the Howe-Moore property, and 1-Îµ/2>0, the set {gâˆˆG;|âŸ¨Ï€â¢(g)â¢x,xâŸ©|â‰¥1-Îµ/2} is compact. It contains Q, hence QÂ¯, so QÂ¯ is compact. It follows that if QÂ¯ is not compact, (Q,Îµ) is a KazhdanÂ pair in G for any Îµâˆˆ(0,2). As a direct consequence of Proposition 7.16, we obtain the following characterization of KazhdanÂ sets in groups without Property (T), but which have the Howe-Moore property.

Theorem 7.17

Let G be a locally compact group with the Howe-Moore property, but without Property (T). A subset Q of G is a KazhdanÂ set in G if and only if QÂ¯ is not compact.

{proof}

We only have to prove that if QÂ¯ is compact, Q is not a KazhdanÂ set in G. This follows directly from the observation that since unitary representations are strongly continuous, Q is a KazhdanÂ set in G as soon as QÂ¯ is a KazhdanÂ set in G. Since G does not have Property (T), it admits no compact KazhdanÂ set, and hence a set with compact closure is not a KazhdanÂ set. As Sâ¢L2â¢(â„) is a non-compact connected simple real Lie group with finite center, it has the Howe-Moore property. But it does not have Property (T), and so we have:

Example 7.18

The KazhdanÂ sets in Sâ¢L2â¢(R) are exactly the subsets of Sâ¢L2â¢(R) with non-compact closure.

8 Further applications of KazhdanÂ sets

8.1 KazhdanÂ sets and local rigidity

It was proved by Rapinchuk [49] that finite dimensional unitary representations of a discrete group G with Property (T) are locally rigid in the following sense: let S be a finite set of generators of G (recall that discrete groups with Property (T) are finitely generated, and that the KazhdanÂ subsets of such groups are the generating sets), and let dâ‰¥1 be an integer. 8.2 KazhdanÂ sets and asymptotically invariant sequences

Connes and Weiss provide ([16], see also [50]) a characterization of Property (T) for countable groups in terms of ergodicity properties of actions of the group on probability spaces. This result is extended in [7, Th.Â 6.3.4] to second countable locally compact groups, and a simplified proof is given there. If G is such a group, and (Î©,â„±,Î½) is a probability space, a measure-preserving action (Tg)gâˆˆG of G on (Î©,â„±,Î½) gives rise to a unitary representation Ï€Î½ of G on L2â¢(Î©,â„±,Î½) defined by setting Ï€Î½â¢(g)â¢fâ¢(Ï‰)=fâ¢(Tg-1â¢Ï‰) for every fâˆˆL2â¢(Î©,â„±,Î½), gâˆˆG and Ï‰âˆˆÎ©. The Connes-Weiss characterization of Property (T) is given in terms of asymptotically invariant sequences (An)nâ‰¥1 of sets for measure preserving actions of G. Given such an action (Tg)gâˆˆG of G on a probability space (Î©,â„±,Î½), these are the sequences (An)nâ‰¥1 of elements of â„± such that for every compact subset Q of G,

Theorem 8.2 ([16])

Let G be a second countable locally compact group. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (a)

    G has Property (T);

  2. (b)

    every measure-preserving ergodic action of G is strongly ergodic;

  3. (c)

    every measure-preserving weakly mixing action of G is strongly ergodic.

We refer the reader to [7, Sec.Â 6.3] or [24, Ch. 13] for more on the consequences of Property (T) on the measure-preserving actions of the group. Our aim here is to present a last consequence of Theorem 2.7, which is a Connes-Weiss type characterization of KazhdanÂ subsets of the group.

Consider a measure-preserving action (Tg)gâˆˆG of G on a probability space (Î©,â„±,Î½), and let Q be a subset of G. Theorem 8.3

Let G be a second countable locally compact group, and let Q be a subset of G which generates G. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (a)

    Q is a KazhdanÂ set in G;

  3. (c)

{proof}

The proof of Theorem 8.3 follows in spirit that of the Connes-Weiss characterization of Property (T) given in [7, Th.Â 6.3.4], and so we will content ourselves with highlighting the main differences between the two proofs. Appendix A Infinite tensor products of Hilbert spaces

We briefly describe in this appendix some constructions of tensor products of infinite families of Hilbert spaces, and of tensor products of infinite families of unitary representations. These last objects play an important role in the proof of Theorem 2.7. We review here the properties and results which we need, following the original works of von Neumann [45] and Guichardet [26].

A.1 The complete and incomplete tensor products of Hilbert spaces

The original construction of the complete and incomplete tensor products of a family (HÎ±)Î±âˆˆI of Hilbert spaces is due to von Neumann [45]. It was later on taken up by Guichardet in [26] under a somewhat different point of view, and the incomplete tensor products of von Neumann are rather known today as the Guichardet tensor products of Hilbert spaces. Although these constructions can be carried out starting from an arbitrary family (HÎ±)Î±âˆˆI of Hilbert spaces, we will present them here only in the case of a countable family (Hn)nâ‰¥1 of (complex) Hilbert spaces.

The complete infinite tensor product âŠ—nâ‰¥1Hn of the Hilbert spaces Hn is defined in [45, PartÂ II,Â Ch.Â 3] in the following way: the elementary infinite tensor products are the elements ğ’™=âŠ—nâ‰¥1xn, where xn belongs to Hn for each nâ‰¥1 and the infinite product âˆnâ‰¥1||xn|| is convergent in the sense of [45, Def.Â 2.2.1], which by [45, Lem.Â 2.4.1] is equivalent to the fact that either xn=0 for some nâ‰¥1 or the series âˆ‘nâ‰¥1maxâ¡(||xn||-1,0) is convergent. Sequences (xn)nâ‰¥1 with this property are called by von Neumann in [45] C-sequences. A scalar product is then defined on the set of finite linear combinations of elementary tensor products by setting

âŸ¨ğ’™,ğ’šâŸ©=âˆnâ‰¥1âŸ¨xn,ynâŸ©

for any elementary tensor products ğ’™=âŠ—nâ‰¥1xn and ğ’š=âŠ—nâ‰¥1yn, and extending the definition by linearity to finite linear combinations of such elements. The incomplete tensor products are closed subspaces of the complete tensor product. They are defined by von Neumann using an equivalence relation between sequences (xn)nâ‰¥1 of vectors with xnâˆˆHn for each nâ‰¥1 and such that the series âˆ‘nâ‰¥1|1-||xn||| is convergent. If (xn)nâ‰¥1 is a C0-sequence, (xn)nâ‰¥1 is bounded, and the series âˆ‘nâ‰¥1|1-||xn||2| is convergent.

Two C0-sequences (xn)nâ‰¥1 and (yn)nâ‰¥1 are equivalent if the series âˆ‘nâ‰¥1|1-âŸ¨xn,ynâŸ©| is convergent. If ğ’œ and ğ’œâ€² are two different equivalence classes, the spaces âŠ—nâ‰¥1ğ’œHn and âŠ—nâ‰¥1ğ’œâ€²Hn are orthogonal, and the linear span of the incomplete tensor products âŠ—nâ‰¥1ğ’œHn, where ğ’œ runs over all equivalence classes of C0-sequences, is dense in the complete tensor product âŠ—nâ‰¥1Hn.
